title.narrative: CSI CDR by Project from Jan-March 2013
CSI Procurment and Recruitment Plan for 2013

description.narrative: Capacity Strengthening Initiative
independent political entity
Accountability - local government finance

Indicators: - Number of areas of intervention identified -Type of capacity needs identified and type of support required - Country specific training resources developed and made available in Arabic -Baselines and targets are established for assessing - Nb of government officials trained -Type of sectors benefiting from specialized expertise -Type of studies/plans carried out -Nb of experts made available (days per year per sector per activity) Engagement of key stakeholder in the needs assessment exercise -Needs assessment of MoLCB, selected local councils and MoI implemented -Strategic response strategic developed -Strategic response integrated in national plans for capacity building -Engagement of women in the assessment process

comment.narrative: Baseline: -Weak technical capacity and knowledge of international best practices in specific units/ areas pertaining to government work -Weak organizational structures and job descriptions -Absence of structured inter-ministerial coordination -Weak capacity of government officials in specific technical and management areas necessary for the government machinery -Weak capacity to identify immediate technical expertise in a timely manner -Lack of government data on experts at the international, regional and local level -Weak institutional connection with the Libyan Diaspora -Weak institutional capacities at key ministries -Capacities of institutions in sync with their new mandates after the revolution -Capacities of institutions unable to respond to urgent planning at the national level

- Roster Management Software to be completed and delivered to Ministry of Planning. - At least two IT specialists from Ministry of Planning to be trained to manage Roster Software. - at least three staff from Technical Cooperation Department/Ministry of planning to take mini-Masters of Business Administration - at least four staff from Ministry of Planning and line ministries to be on strategic planning.

- Roster Management Software completed and successfully delivered to Ministry of Planning. - Two IT specialists from Ministry of Planning trained to manage and run the Roster Software. - Three employees from Technical Cooperation Department/Ministry of planning enrolled and completed mini-Masters of Business Administration

1. Type of capacity needs identified and type of support required 2. Number of government officials trained 3. Type of sectors benefiting from specialized expertise 4. Nb of experts made available (days per year per sector per activity)

The support provided by UNDP by deploying embedded technical experts at the ministry of planning increased the efficiency of the ministry in dealing with international community with regard to assistance to Libya. Moreover, the UNDP support to Line ministries related to Government Programme Planning and policy formulation process enhanced the skills of government staff.

title.narrative: Support to Civic Engagement in Libya’s Transition SCELT

description.narrative: Support to Civic Engagement in Libya’s Transition SCELT

title.narrative: Support to Civic Engagement in Libya?s Transition SCELT

description.narrative: Support to Civic Engagement in
independent political entity
Other General Services - support to civil society

Indicators: - NGO law imitated drafted and submitted. - consultation dialogue with NGO’ concerning the drafted law undertaken - international relevant experience exposed - Nb of students benefiting directly from civic education classes and/or model democratic processes - Nb of reference materials produced for teachers and students - Nb of edutainment products - Nb of monitoring initiatives led by youth - Nb of monitoring reports on youth issues & transition disseminated to decision-makers - Advocacy by civil society on enhancing the role of women in transition - Nb of professional Libyan facilitators - Number of CSOs receiving sub-grants and implementing activities - Number of CSOs receiving financial management and implementation mentoring and support - Increase in capacity [May 2016 ] among targeted CSOs compared to baseline capacity assessment [October 2015] - Web Portal on-line, accessible, up-to-date and used by up to 50 CSOs - Web & App Designer agreement signed - Format for Web Portal & Mobile App designed - Number of CSOs using Beta version of web portal/app [disaggregated according to female and male-lead organisations with minimum 50% female] - Number of CSOs using Web portal/App in first week following Launch [disaggregated according to female and male-lead organisation with minimum 50% female]

comment.narrative:
Baseline: - Libyan NGO legislation does not protect freedom of expression and association ; only adhoc measures have been taken post-revolution to facilitate NGO registration - Absence of evidence-based knowledge of civic education needs - No coordination and information-sharing
- Knowledge of democracy & good governance among the youth in Libya is limited, but desire to engage actively in the transition is very high - Total student population is 250,000. - Lack of reference materials and outreach products on civic education adapted to the youth - No independent monitoring of the transition done according to credible indicator framework - Youth issues not sufficiently mainstreaming into public policies
- No government strategy to improve the role of women in building peace and democracy in Libya. - Nascent women’s rights movement in Libya. - Women are traditionally kept out of the political sphere.
- Lack of qualified dialogue facilitators in Libya and limited training opportunities - No framework for national dialogue and lack of dialogue culture - Certain population groups with little access to dialogue opportunities.

• Up to 15 sub-grants are provided to CS organisations to implement activities • 15 key CS organizations will be targeted with capacity development and mentoring in the implementation of activities supported through sub-grants • A national mapping report of all CSO’s across Libya will be launched • A national Web Portal on Civil Society in Libya will be managed and updated monthly, • National associations of Libyan CSOs developed through 3 quarterly workshops staring with Libyan Civil Society Rroundtable • Baseline Study on Women, Peace and Security [currently being finalized] revised and updated to reflect current political context; Recommendations adjusted to match the current security situation and the conflict/post-conflict phase. Launch event in Tunis of Baseline Study and Comparative Analysis on Women Peace & Security in Libya, • Libyan CSO capacity for civic education and engagement will be developed through the Civic Engagement Grant Fund to provide basic knowledge of democratic governance among youth and women across Libya. • A youth leadership development programme targeting 30 key youth leaders across the country will be implemented • Multi-Level Civic Learning for Women and Girls through a Training Of Facilitators for 30 Libyan young women who will then develop and provide general Civic Education initiatives targeted at 20K women and girls • A democratic dialogue & Conflict analysis toolkit targeting women and youth CSOs will be developed, • Training of Dialogue Facilitators & Mediators Programme targeting 20 Libyan facilitators [70% youth and women] • Up to 20 grass-roots dialogue and mediation processes will be initiated at grass-roots level at key community flashpoints [Based on local context and conflict analysis]

• CEGF, Phase II [May-December 2015] was launched by UNDP in May 2015 with the aim of distributing and managing small grants to selected Libyan CSOs while developing their capacity in the design, development, management and implementation of projects that focus on civic education for women and girls, dialogue and mediation, and youth leadership development. 14 CSO`s where granted. • Despite a challenging security environment in Libya, the CSOs were able to complete their project activities with minor adjustments and deviations in timeframes, locations, and activities, necessary given the situation on the ground. Through the 14 projects implemented, a wide range of activities covering the three thematic areas were implemented, reaching more than 2,516 direct beneficiaries and more than 92,919 indirect beneficiaries in the South, Middle, East and West regions of the country2. Among the activities were 75 workshops and 39 discussion sessions on dialogue and facilitation and peace awareness among citizens, civil society, local councils, among others; 20 awareness raising campaigns on the role of youth and women in peacebuilding, people with disabilities’ participation, civic engagement, and human rights; 50 field visits and volunteering activities targeting youth, secondary school teachers and local authorities (Local Councils, Municipalities and Elderly Councils of Ajdabia

• Civic Engagement Grant Fund Phase 3: Twelve sub-grants are provided to CS organisations to implement Output 2-4 activities over a 4 month period • Twelve key CS organizations will be targeted with capacity development and mentoring in proposal development, financial management and the implementation of activities supported through sub-grants • A national Web Portal/Mobile on Civil Society in Libya will be designed and managed and updated monthly • Training: Libyan CSO capacity for civic education and engagement will be developed through the Civic Engagement Grant Fund through targeted training based on capacity assessment for 32 CSOs • CSO implemented activities under Grant Fund in 1- Women & girls civic education and engagement, 2- Youth leadership & engagement, 3- Conflict analysis and dialogue facilitation 4- Promoting dialogue and responsiveness & accountability of Municipalities to citizen engagement in supporting effective services; • Development of CSO Toolkits in: - Women & Girls Civic education - Youth Engagement & Leadership - Conflict Analysis and Dialogue - Civic engagement with Municipalities

• Through the 13 projects implemented, there was a wide range of workshops and awareness-raising activities implemented, regions covered, and target groups reached (directly and indirectly). A total of approximately 209 activities were implemented under the 13 grant fund projects. In total, 100 workshops, 31 discussion sessions / dialogue debate sessions and 11 media & awareness raising campaigns, 22 field visits were conducted and 34 videos were produced, reaching approximately more than 1,821 direct beneficiaries (approximately 45% women and 55% men) and more than 30,775 indirect beneficiaries in the South, East, Middle, and West regions of the country. These numbers are approximate as in some cases the CSOs did not report numbers of beneficiaries desegregated by gender, and others did not report on indirect beneficiaries although their outreach did extend beyond the direct beneficiaries that participated in the activities • A national Web Portal/Mobile on Civil Society in Libya had developed with almost 200 Libyan CSO`s registered. (NGOS.ly) • CSO Toolkit in; - Women & Girls Civic education, - Youth Engagement & Leadership, - Conflict Analysis and Dialogue, - Civic engagement with Municipalities had developed and handed over to the 12 CSO`s granted for CEGF phase III. • On the regional and south to south corporation level the project had funded: 1- Three Libyan CSO`s representatives to attend “Arab Regional Conference on the Role of Civil Society in Implementing Agenda 2030 for Sustainable Development” scheduled on 20-21 April 2016 in Doha, (Qatar). 2- Two Libyan youth activists to attended Youth, Peace, and Security in the Arab States Region: A Consultation and High-level Dialogue 4 – 6 December 2016 Amman (Jordan)

description.narrative: Libya Electoral Assistance Project (LEAP)
Libya Electoral Assistance Project (LEAP)
independent political entity
Elections - elections

(1) Transitional authorities manage fair and inclusive democratic processes (Source: CPD 2012-15) (2) Transparent, credible elections; results accepted by the Libyan electorate (Source LEAP M&E Framework, 2013) (3) Electoral institutions and practices adhering to international good practices enshrined in emerging national legal framework (Source: LEAP M&E Framework, 2013)

comment.narrative: (1) National congress replaces NTC and launches democratic processes in 2012 (Source: CPD 2012-15) (2) No national elections held in Libya since 1965 (Source: LEAP 2012 Project Document) (3) Electoral management body sworn in on 12 February 2012; new body has minimal capacity (Source: LEAP 2012 Project Document)

(1) Organizational, management and operational capacities are in place to manage transitional democratic processes (Source: CPD 2012-15; note: annual targets not defined). (2) In context of deteriorating political and security environment, satisfaction of at least 84% of the population with conduct of electoral event (Source: LEAP 2015 M&E Framework). (3) 2014 observation/assessment missions provide equally positive assessments as in 2012 (Source: LEAP 2015 M&E Framework).

(1) Information not available; no electoral process held in 2015 (Source: LEAP 2015 Annual Report). (2) Information not available; no electoral process held in 2015 (Source: LEAP 2015 Annual Report). (3) Information not available; no observer missions in 2015 (Source: LEAP 2015 Annual Report).

1) HNEC's organisational, management, and technical capacities to plan, prepare and manage successive credible and transparent elections are strengthened. 2) awareness and knowledge of critical electoral issues strengthened.

1) Finalizing an electoral gender mapping document 2) supporting the HNEC with voter registration software training 3) working closely with IFES with HNEC senior management on designing a plan for voter education and public outreach strategy for potential referendum event

description.narrative: Targeted technical support to assist the Government of Libya to build the capacity of transitional governance structures.
independent political entity
Elections - elections

comment.narrative: Local Government - Local governments have limited capacity for development planning, budgeting and implementation; lack of dependable data/ statistics on demography and service users Parliamentary Support - No recent history of an elected parliament and its role in a democratic society - Little understanding of parliamentary functions of roles by elected MPs - Limited consultative engagement between parliament and citizens - No recent history of parliamentary groups Constitution - Elections were held in July 2012 but no constitution yet in place. Elections for the Constitution Drafting Assembly are expected to take place in December 2013. According to the Constitutional Declaration a constitutional referendum is currently foreseen for 2014. The GNC was put in place in August 2013 but there is limited parliamentary experience. Rule of Law & Human Rights: Lack of clear procedures which contribute to slowness in processing cases; lack of access to legal materials by judges and staff; public’s lack of awareness of their legal rights and legal procedures; inadequate information available for public awareness of legal rights; women face difficulties in access to justice; no system to ensure sustainability of reforms
1. Continue to provide technical support and expertise to the CDA administration to enhance its operations and modus operandi especially when it comes to public consultation and outreach
XXXX

1.The CDA has been provided with the means to implement public consultation and outreach process for receiving public consultations. 2.The CDA provided with assistance in media and communication. 3.Libyan population receive informed messages on the constitution making process and substance. 4.Libyan academia and other key stakeholders have been engaged in the constitution-making process through the production of papers, organization of public debates and workshops. Libyan population engaged in the constitution-making through participation in targeted survey. 5.Enhanced coordination between Libyan and international actors in the constitution-making process. 6.CSOs/NGOs are equipped with the necessary tools, instruments and capacity to effectively engage media and outreach campaign.
XXXX

description.narrative: Support to Dialogue Project

participating-org.narrative: US Department of State, Office to monitor & combat Tracking in persons.

description.narrative: Other General Services - support to civil society

provider-org.narrative: US Department of State, Office to monitor & combat Tracking in persons.
US Department of State, Office to monitor & combat Tracking in persons.

description.narrative: 1- Inclusiveness of dialogue process. 2- Incorporation of women's demands into draft political agreement. 3 - Safe and neutral platform provided for dialogue. 4- GNA national programme priorities defined. 5- Number of national priorities for GNA identified for project support with policy strategy and implementation plan. 6- Capacity strengthened in supported institutions.

comment.narrative: 1- Major Libyan political actors involved in various dialogue meetings. 2- No women's demands included in the draft political agreement. 3- Willingness exists amongst participants to meet 4- No national priorities for GNA defined. 5- No national priorities for GNA defined. 6-Supported institutions not defined and no capacity assessment undertaken.

(A) Continued participation of major Libyan political actors in dialogue.
(B) Majority of women's demands included in draft political agreement.
(C) Safe and neutral platform continues to be provided as an opportunity for addressing disputes in a non-violent manner.

a) UNDP support to UNSMIL’s brokered peace processes managed to bring all Libyans including political parties, tribal leaders and security staff and women to participate in dialogue process. UNDP procured more than 1200 tickets bringing together Libyans to dialogue and peace agreement. The overall efforts of UNDP resulted in signing the Libyan Political Agreement (LPA) in December 2015.
b) As part of one the tracks for the project, UNDP supported the advocacy efforts of UNSMIL to establish the Women’s demands and expands the role of women political decisions. After several meetings women participants of the dialogue processes were able to include the women unit at Presidential Council. This unit will have a role to advocate for women’s rights.
c) The UNDP support created an enabling environment for Libyans to discuss the countries burning issues. The supported provided by UNDP resulted in establishing a Government of National Accord.

1. Main political dialogue process towards implementation supported 2. Incorporation of women's demands into draft political agreement 3. Safe and neutral platform for inter-tribal political dialogue provided 4. Dialogues towards improved security supported 5. National priorities for GNA identified for project support in selected institutions identified 6. Core government functions re-established

1-The project most recently supported a major political dialogue in Malta in November 2016 which called on the HoR to amend the Constitutional Declaration to incorporate the Libyan Political Agreement (LPA), and on the PC to address the dismal security, social and economic problems facing the people of Libya
2-The project has supported the inclusion of the establishment of a women support unit in the LPA. The project’s support to the LPA implementation has further contributed to the formalized establishment of the unit
3-The project has supported cross-community reconciliation between Misrata and Tawergha, which have resulted in a breakthrough signing of an agreement on 30 August 2016 stipulating the “return of the displaced and compensation of those affected”.
4-The UNDP political dialogue project has supported UNSMIL to assist the Presidency Council (PC) appoint a Temporary Security Committee (TSC), as outlined in the LPA. The TSC meeting facilitated by the project/UNSMIL enabled the PC and the TSC to agree on a Tripoli security plan, and the establishment of a Presidential Guard
5-The project is assisting GNA re-establish core government functions by strengthen the overall technical administrative competency and skills of its staff. To this effect the project has initiated the recruitment of international and Libyan experts to build the capacity of the Libyan public administration
6-The project is assisting the GNA to re-establish core government functions in order to generate evidence based, factually strong policy recommendations to assist GNA reform and rebuild the public sector art large. The first assessment on Government Employees / Civil Service Reform has been completed, while three others are underway.

title.narrative: Strengthen ROL /access to justice in transition period

description.narrative: The Project aims at developing capacities of key RoL institutions , Improve access to justice of the Libyan population; and support to the implementation of Transitional Justice process for national reconciliation.
Support to Rule of Law and Access to Justice Project
independent political entity
Justice, Law and Order - policy, planning and administration

1. Utilisation of criminal and civil courts and rise in level of public confidence. 2. JID undertakes more regular inspections and deeper analysis and produces regular reports 3. Relevant actors, including civil society, actively engaged with the transitional justice process and outreach / information campaign underway.

comment.narrative: •Distribution of justice services remains uneven, infrastructure is damaged, security is inadequate and court administration is weak. •Nationally identified need for judicial law reform to harmonise legislation and ensure compliance with international standards. •Lack of an up-to-date institutional capacity assessment of the judiciary; absence of continuing legal and judicial education and training programme. •Sparse availability of information / data on current judicial performance; lack of capacity within the JID for statistical and data analysis. •Limited capacities within the MOJ for management, operations and strategic planning.

1. Relevant actors, including civil society, actively engaged with the transitional justice process and outreach / information campaign underway. 2. The TSRC operationalizes key aspects of its mandate as specified in law. 3.- National consensus on Transitional Justice strengthened through dialogue.

title.narrative: Programme for Libya’s Resilience and Recovery

description.narrative: Programme for Libya’s Resilience and Recovery – PL2R
Programme for Libya’s Resilience and Recovery – PL2R
capital of a political entity

- Level of use of conflict-related development analysis tools for local recovery / development planning. - Number of municipalities equipped with reliable and updatable baseline on LGLD conditions - Number of local (municipal) conflict and gender-sensitive recovery plans prepared in 2014 -- Availability of reliable evidence and innovative thinking pieces upon which long-term economic recovery and sustainable human development policies can be built. - Availability of reliable evidence and innovative thinking pieces upon which long-term economic recovery and sustainable human development policies can be built.

comment.narrative: - Conflict analysis tools in Libya focus mostly on political dimension and are not well localized. - Very few municipalities have exhaustive LGLD baselines, mostly old and patchy sectorial statistics; governance-related indicators are unheard of. - A handful of municipalities received assistance for integrated LD plans (3-5 y) but results unclear. - Most of the current research and policy-setting agenda in Libya is dominated by the political transition file; there is a dearth of prospective thinking on Libya’s challenges (beyond instability and conflict) for achieving sustainable human development goals -- UNDP Libya’s 80% (all programme) stood at $13, 526, 199 (2014), highly constrained by its relocation to Tunis and the funding shortfall for its operational costs. - In 2013, UNDP Libya produced a programme document on local governance & decentralisation that prioritized policy support for legal reform and institution-building (top-down). It is not appropriate to current Libya’s context.

- Conflict-related development analysis method and tools available and tested in 5 municipalities. - Very few municipalities have exhaustive LGLD baselines, mostly old and patchy sectorial statistics; governance-related indicators are unheard of. - one-year Local Resilience & Recovery Plans (LRRPs) developed.

description.narrative:
O. 1 - Number of municipal needs assessments conducted - Number of light infrastructure rehabilitated - Number of equipment provided - Number of critical businesses rehabilitated
O. 2 - Number of capacity assessments - Number of technical experts deployed - Number of local authorities with increased capacity O. 3 - Number of local assessments conducted - Number of civic engagement campaigns - Number of youth and women engaged - Number of municipalities trained and engaged in conflict resolution efforts

comment.narrative:
Output 1: Light infrastructure destroyed by conflict rehabilitated and recovery of critical businesses supported Key infrastructure destroyed in the intensified conflict since mid-2014 disrupting the regular functioning of hospitals, schools, roads, electricity networks, power grids, police stations, and water facilities - Local businesses (MSMEs) impacted by the crisis. - Lack of viable economic opportunities for jobs and income generation for youth, including vulnerable groups (IDPs, returnees, and migrants).
Output 2: Immediate capacity boost to municipalities provided - Municipalities lack human resource and financial capacity to effective function in their role as local authorities. - Traditional and weak bureaucratic systems in local institutions (municipalities and executive bodies) - Current partnership building between local actors is ad hoc, externally driven, unstructured and reactive. - Inadequate levels of financial transparency. - Limited engagement with civil society and media. - Marked decrease in access to and quality of basic services in certain areas and even more so for the 700,000 persons of concern (IDPs, refugees, migrants).
Output 3: Local conflict analysis, facilitation and mediation capacity strengthened - Role of municipalities in mediation and conflict resolution remains ad hoc. - Traditional leaders and structures play an important role in local mediation and conflict mitigation, but these efforts mainly act as mitigation of escalation following an incident, rather than as an effective peacebuilding mechanism. - Existing conflict management and dialogue efforts at local level are not sufficiently visible, remain ad hoc and reactive rather than preventative. - Level of violent criminality and threats against private property increasing across the country. - Protective system for women against violence is weak, due to institutional and cultural barriers.

O. 1 Rapid needs assessment carried out in all municipalities where the project will be implemented 100% of agreed light infrastructure works completed in the selected municipalities (the exact number and nature of the works will be defined by the needs assessment) 100% of agreed MSMEs rehabilitated and 100% of the agreed equipment provided (the exact number and nature of the MSMEs and required equipment will be defined by the needs assessment)
O. 2 Capacity gaps assessed in all municipalities where the programme is being implemented. Based on the agreed requirements, technical experts deployed in selected municipalities to build capacity. Municipal strategic plans developed in all agreed locations
O. 3 Strategic partnerships with four NGOs working in Libya initiated. Localized conflict analysis completed in areas identified by the board. Capacity of municipal and local leaders on conflict resolution enhanced At least two civic engagement campaigns led by youth organizations.

O. 1 - Needs assessment conducted in 3 municipalities (Benghazi, Kikla and Obari) - Initial assessment on conflict dynamics conducted in Sirte municipality - 22 civil works to rehabilitate damaged infrastructure identified as priority (15 brought to tender) - 30 equipment needs identified and prioritized (17 brought to tender) - 11 regular ambulances & 11 ICU ambulances delivered to support access to health services in three municipalities - 8 garbage trucks delivered to enhance public health in 3 municipalities
O. 2 - Delivery Advisor hired and providing technical assistance to Ministry of Plan - Recruitment of Municipal Liaison Office finalized; will begin 1 January 2017 - Communications training implemented in December (2 specialists from each project site: Benghazi, Kikla, and Obari plus 2 from Presidential Council, PC)
O. 3 - Perception survey initiated on view of citizens on service delivery of the GNA and Municipalities - Consultations with Tribal Leaders from Benghazi, Kikla and Obari conducted to identify conflict mitigation measures needed and their monitoring - 3 municipalities engaged in conflict resolution efforts (social peace partnerships established in 2)

title.narrative: Advancing Libyan Women’s Participation During the Transi

title.narrative: Advance Women Participation in the Political Transition
Advancing Libyan Women?s Participation During the Transi

description.narrative: AMEL project " Advancing Libyan Women’s Participation During the transition"
capital of a political entity

activity-description.narrative: The project will support the advancement of participation of Libyan women in decision making during the political transition phase.

description.narrative: capital of a political entity
Social Protection, Land Housing and Community Amenities - social services (incl youth development and women+ children)

comment.narrative: • Article 12 in the Political Agreement Stipulates the establishment of the Women’s Support and Empowerment Unit in the Presidential Council. • The CEDAW of Libya has been ratified. • • Women’s Agenda for Peace developed by a group of key Libyan women with the support of UNSMIL. • Advocacy and Pressure Group on the Presidency Council established and has eight members. • No jointly agreed approach by the international community on gender engagement in Libya.
1. HOR conference for women parliamentarians 2. Pressure group meeting

 A consultative meeting was held on 21-23 October 2016, with the Advocacy and Lobby group (LWAF). The meeting aimed to assist the group to continue their advocacy work on women’s political participation. the outcome of the consultative meeting was as follows: • New name for the group as Libyan Women Advocacy Forces (LWF). • Developed LWAF mandate, identify, objectives and vision. • Developed slogan and log for the LWAF. • Develop a mini-communication strategy. • Developed coordination strategy for the group • Developed a code of conduct. • Developed internal conflict resolutions mechanism for the group.  Furthermore LWAF met on with Ms. Margot Wallstrom, the minister of Foreign Affairs, Sweden. LWAF presented the priorities of Libyan women as well as discussed concrete Swedish support to Libyan women initiatives, in light of the possible Swedish 2016-2020 MENA strategy.  A Libyan Parliamentarian Women three days conference organized towards effective role in the House of Representatives. Women parliamentarians from neighbouring countries such as Tunis, Algeria, Egypt, Sudan, Chad and Niger would were also invited. At the end result of the conference: • Confidence and solidarity among Libyan female members of the HoRs enhanced; • Female members of the HoRs are informed of ways to be effective in their functions; • Female members of HoRs created network with female members from the neighboring countries; • Female members of the HoRs build consensus around issues pertaining working together for one common goal.
